yeah you're spot on, The board brought a COO, Brian Gray, in, Brian was a great guy, very grounded and did his best to keep everyone's feet on the ground. But you hit the nail on the head with "wishful thinking". At one stage Mike had had enough of sales guys and decided to lead that side of the business. Wishing that Quest deal over the line was the final downfall though, no eye on any other option or on the possibility that the deal may fall through.¬†  When it did fall through, as we were planning Future Scapa, (without him, he came to me and proposed pretty much the same plan, except this version had him in it., We had to tell him then and there that we saw his involvement as a massive distraction. Plus the board wouldn't have let him away with it.
I shudder to think how bad he got after I left.

Mike's issue at heart was that despite his intelligence, he made abysmal decisions that weren't remotely in the interests of the company. Mike's analysis was hopelessly clouded by wishful thinking and there was nobody left to tell him he was wrong.

In many ways I liked the guy. Mike was smart as hell, always full of ideas and I learned a lot from him. He founded a company, got together a good group of engineers,¬† persuaded investors to put in millions to support it.¬†  But as a leader you were either with him or against him. There was a sort of Cult of Mike. Dave was always 100% behind him. Lyndon wasn't, so Mike pushed him out of the company using a bullshit accusation of hacking 'uncovered' by that weaselly shitbag Sniadowski. The company quickly got autocratic after that.¬† Ben and I got jaded, so we had to go too. That was 3 / 4 of the original development team gone in 2 years, all because we weren't on Team Mike.
and for all the galaxy brain thinking that Mike did, I think he was found out. The IBM buying Scapa thing was real tooth fairy stuff
LOL, exactly. Got fuck all out of it
A little while later I gave in my notice.

For me the obvious thing to do was cut our losses with Eclipse and look for other business opportunities, but instead they doubled down on Eclipse, which seemed like madness. We were just building IBM's platform for them, for free, while they were not only massive but our major competitor.
I thought about this a lot and realised, just like Lyndon had warned me long before, that sometimes Mike was just completely full of shit.

So I kept my head down in I think winter 2002-3, then the news broke that IBM had bought Rational, which meant they now had their own stress-testing tool. I told Mike we were fucked, and he replied that Scapa would be bought as well, as part of the deal.

Then when Ben left and they didn't offer me CTO (a post they'd offered me when Lyndon left but I didn't want it because Ben would have walked) I knew I was done. They wanted to fire me but I never gave them cause.
I thought it was insane to close down a product with such potential as Citrix and lose Ben in the bargain.
The company was Mike's product, and he was going to see it to IBM. So they threw resources behind Eclipse, with me self-sidelined, closed down Citrix so that Ben walked.

I turned down leadership of the Eclipse thing in I think 2002, because it sounded like a massive distraction with no obvious payoff. I didn't immediately understand that I'd signed my death warrant with the company, because Eclipse was the opportunity Mike had been looking for.
Did Neil get laid off then? You mentioned he came back as a consultant later.

yeah that's pretty much it, the product was going nowhere, we expended a huge amount of energy to deploy it with Eclipse, and customers by and large hated it. Mike's focus was on selling up. But the main revenue was consulting, with the occasional license sale. It was still running the conceit of being a small-medium software co. There had been a couple of rounds of layoffs preceding the big blow up.
(I take it back. There's no alternative timeline where Mike listens to people)
(obviously there's an alternate timeline where Mike listens to Ben instead of ignoring him, Citrix gets developed properly and Scapa gets bought out three years later)

yeah he did well. I bumped into him at a Citrix event a few years afterwards, it was good to see him. The bastard.

Mike and Dave were proper furious about it and brought in the lawyers, but Ben had kept a copy of the email where they'd told him they weren't going to pursue the idea.

The real winner in all of this was Ben. He figured out a way to make Citrix work properly but Mike and Dave told him they didn't want to do it. So Ben went off and did it with his own company, Thin Genius.

he did not, rending of cloth was followed by threats of legal etc. He took a payoff and we all ended up friends again, He got into cybersecurity and was working at JP Morgan the last I heard
